notes: Converting $$\int_{0}^t\int_{|\xi| = 1} f(x + s\xi) dS_{\xi} ds$$ to $$\int_{B_3(t)} \frac{f(y)}{|y|^2} dy$$ via $y = x + s\xi)$ took way too long. Basically, if you scale $\xi$ by $s$, you pick up an extra $s^2$ area. For fixed angles defining the area $dS_{\xi}$ at distance $1$ from the origin, when you scale the vector by $s$, each side length of $S_{\xi}$ gets scaled by $s$, so the total area is scaled by $s^2$.
Breaking for lunch, but problems for plane waves in 3 dimensions
